bioghist.p: Alan N. Polasky became a professor of Law at the University of Michigan in 1957. Prior to coming to Michigan Polasky taught law at Northwestern University and practiced privately in Illinois and Iowa Polasky received his J.D. degree from the University of Iowa in 1951. That institution also awarded him a B.S. degree in accounting in 1947. Polasky became a certified public accountant in 1948.

Polasky's greatest areas of legal interest were in rules of evidence and estate law. In the latter he was recognized as a national expert. He spoke widely on the subject, and served as a member or chairman of several American Bar Association committees dealing with various aspects of estate planning. Polasky died suddenly in 1976.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Alan Polasky divide themselves into six series: Biographical, Correspondence, Professional affiliations, Speeches, Subject files and Material relating to the University of Michigan.

The correspondence files, covering the years 1958 through 1976, are arranged chronologically. Apparently duplicate copies of this file were arranged by subject, however much of this material was lost.

Included under "Professional affiliations" are materials relating to the American Bar Association (ABA) in general and its committees regarding "Real Property, Probate and Trust Law" and Taxation in specific. There is also a great deal of information regarding the ABA's Uniform Disposition of Community Property At Death model legislation. The American Bar Foundation and organizations interested in appellate court reform are also represented in this group.

scopecontent.p: The Speeches series is incomplete. Those speeches which remain cover the years 1959 through 1976. Many of the extant folders contain only summaries or outlines of Polasky's remarks. In some instances there is merely a letter stating the subjects that will be covered.

scopecontent.p: The subject file represents material that may have been intended for interfiling elsewhere in the collection, but which was not finished at the time of Polasky's death. It is arranged alphabetically.

Polasky's University of Michigan material deals primarily with the Law School. It contains a copy of his lectures on estate planning, and also a good deal of information about proposed curriculum changes in the Law School.
